patterns: What to do if Cuts?
How to cure Cuts?
Which medicine to apply for Cuts?
what to apply on cuts?
Cuts
responses: Wash the cut properly to prevent infection and stop the bleeding by applying pressure for 1-2minutes until bleeding stops. Apply Petroleum Jelly to make sure that the wound is moist for quick healing. Finally cover the cut with a sterile bandage. Pain relievers such as acetaminophen can be applied.

patterns: how do you treat abrasions?
Do Abrasions cause scars?
Abrasions
what to do if abrasions?
Which medicine to apply for abrasions?
How to cure abrasions?
responses: Begin with washed hands.Gently clean the area with cool to lukewarm water and mild soap. Remove dirt or other particles from the wound using sterilized tweezers.For a mild scrape that's not bleeding, leave the wound uncovered.If the wound is bleeding, use a clean cloth or bandage, and apply gentle pressure to the area to stop any bleeding.Cover a wound that bled with a thin layer of topical antibiotic ointment, like Bacitracin, or a sterile moisture barrier ointment, like Aquaphor. Cover it with a clean bandage or gauze. Gently clean the wound and change the ointment and bandage once per day.Watch the area for signs of infection, like pain or redness and swelling. See your doctor if you suspect infection.

patterns: How do you treat Sting?
Stings
What to do if you get a sting?
Which medicine to apply if sting?
responses: Remove any stingers immediately. Some experts recommend scraping out the stinger with a credit card. Applying ice to the site may provide some mild relief. Apply ice for 20 minutes once every hour as needed. Wrap the ice in a towel or keep a cloth between the ice and skin to keep from freezing the skin. Taking an antihistamine such as diphenhydramine (Benadryl) or a nonsedating one such as loratadine (Claritin) will help with itching and swelling. Take acetaminophen (Tylenol) or ibuprofen (Motrin)for pain relief as needed. Wash the sting site with soap and water. Placing hydrocortisone cream on the sting can help relieve redness, itching, and swelling.

patterns: How to remove Splinters
How to cure Splinters?
What to do if I have splinters?
How do you bring a splinter to the surface?
responses: 1. SOAK IT IN EPSOM SALTS. Dissolve a cup of the salts into a warm bath and soak whatever part of the body has the splinter. Failing that, you can also put some of the salts onto a bandage pad and leave it covered for a day; this will eventually help bring the splinter to the surface. 2. VINEGAR OR OIL. Another simple way to draw out that stubborn splinter is to soak the affected area in oil (olive or corn) or white vinegar. Just pour some in a bowl and soak the area for around 20 to 30 minutes,

patterns: How do you treat a sprain?
what to do if i get a sprain?
Which cream to apply if i get a sprain?
Which medicine to apply if I get a sprain?
responses: Use an ice pack or ice slush bath immediately for 15 to 20 minutes and repeat every two to three hours while you're awake. To help stop swelling, compress the ankle with an elastic bandage until the swelling stops. In most cases, pain relievers — such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) or naproxen sodium (Aleve, others) or acetaminophen (Tylenol, others) are enough to manage the pain of a sprained ankle.

patterns: How do you treat a strain?
what to do if i get a strain?
Which cream to apply if i get a strain?
Which medicine to apply if I get a strain?
How do you diagnose a strain?
Is heat or ice better for a pulled muscle?
responses: Rest,Ice,Compression and Elevation can be used to cure strains. Avoid using your muscle for a few days, especially if movement causes an increase in pain and also Apply ice immediately after injuring your muscle. This will minimize swelling. Don't put ice directly on your skin. Use an ice pack or wrap ice in a towel. To reduce swelling, wrap the affected area with an elastic bandage until swelling comes down.

patterns: How do you treat a mild Fever?
what to do if i get a mild fever?
Which medicine to take if I get a mild fever?
fever
responses: To treat a fever at home: 1)Drink plenty of fluids to stay hydrated. 2)Dress in lightweight clothing. 3)Use a light blanket if you feel chilled, until the chills end. 4)Take acetaminophen (Tylenol, others) or ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others). 5) Get medical help if the fever lasts more than five days in a row.

patterns: How do you treat nasal Congestion?
what to do if i get a nasal congestion?
Which medicine to take if I have a nasal congestion?
what to do if i have a blocked nose?
How do you treat a blocked nose?
How long does nasal congestion last?
responses: When you're stuffed up, focus on keeping your nasal passages and sinuses moist. To keep your nasal passages moist, you can: 1)Use a humidifier or vaporizer. 2)Drink lots of fluids. This will thin out your mucus, which could help prevent blocked sinuses. 3)Place a warm, wet towel on your face. It may relieve discomfort and open your nasal passages.

patterns: How to cure cough?
How do you treat cough?
what to do if i get a cough?
Which medicine to take if I get cough?
How do you get rid of cough?
responses: 1) Honey:- Use honey to treat a cough, mix 2 teaspoons (tsp) with warm water or an herbal tea. Drink this mixture once or twice a day. Do not give honey to children under 1 year of age. 2) Ginger:- Brew up a soothing ginger tea by adding 20–40 grams (g) of fresh ginger slices to a cup of hot water. Allow to steep for a few minutes before drinking. Add honey or lemon juice to improve the taste and further soothe a cough. 3) Fluids:- Staying hydrated is vital for those with a cough or cold. Research indicates that drinking liquids at room temperature can alleviate a cough, runny nose, and sneezing.

patterns: How do you treat sore throat?
what to do if i get a sore throat?
Which medicine to take if I get a sore throat?
How to cure sore throat?
responses: 1) Make sure you get plenty of rest and drink a lot of fluids. 2)Inhale steam,Run hot water in a sink.Drape a towel over you to trap the steam, and have the person lean over the sink with the water running. Tell him to breathe deeply through his mouth and nose for 5 to 10 minutes. Repeat several times a day. 3)Have him sip chicken broth or warm tea with honey. Don't give honey to a child under 12 months of age.

patterns: How do you treat gas problems?
what to do if i have Gastrointestinal problems?
Which medicine to take if I get gas problem?
How to cure Gas problems?
responses: 1) Replenish body fluids 2)Do not take antidiarrheal drugs or laxatives or pain medication, unless specified by a medical professional.3)Taking antacids may help, per recommendation of a healthcare professional. 4)If prone to frequent heartburns, seek medical help. 5)Taking meals that are not spicy regularly, can relieve ulcer pains. 6)Seek medical help, if conditions persist or continue to worsen

patterns: How do you treat Skin problems?
what to do if i get a skin allergy?
Which medicine to take if I get a skin allergy?
How to cure skin allergy?
responses: 1)Hydrocortisone cream. 2)Ointments like calamine lotion. 3)Antihistamines. 4)Cold compresses. 5)Oatmeal baths. 6)Talk to your doctor about what's best for your specific rash.

patterns: How do you treat Abdominal Pain?
what to do if i get a Abdominal Pain?
Which medicine to take if I get a Abdominal Pain?
How to cure Abdominal Pain?
responses: 1)Provide clear fluids to sip, such as water, broth, or fruit juice diluted with water. 2)Serve bland foods, such as saltine crackers, plain bread, dry toast, rice, gelatin, or applesauce. 3)Avoid spicy or greasy foods and caffeinated or carbonated drinks until 48 hours after all symptoms have gone away.

patterns: How do you treat Bruises?
what to do if i get a Bruise?
Which medicine to take if I get a Bruise?
How to cure Bruises?
responses: 1)Ice the bruise with an ice pack wrapped in a towel. 2)Leave it in place for 10 to 20 minutes. 3)Repeat several times a day for a day or two as needed. 4)Compress the bruised area if it is swelling, using an elastic bandage.

patterns: How do you treat a Broken Toe?
what to do if i get a Broken Toe?
Which medicine to take if I get a Broken Toe?
How to cure Broken Toe?
responses: 1)To help decrease pain and swelling in a broken toe, elevate the foot, ice the injury, and stay off the foot. 2)Depending on the severity of the fracture, the toe may need to be put back into place (reduced), and some compound toe fractures may require surgery.3) Most broken toes heal without complications in six weeks.

patterns: How do you treat Choking?
what to do if i get a Choke?
Which medicine to take if I get Choked?
How to cure Choking?
responses: 1)Encourage them to keep coughing to try to clear the blockage. 2)Ask them to try to spit out the object if it's in their mouth. 3)If coughing doesn't work, start back blows and Abdominal thrusts

patterns: How do you treat a wound?
what to do if i get a Wound?
Which medicine to take if I get wounded?
How to cure a wound?
responses: 1)Rinse the cut or wound with water and apply pressure with sterile gauze, a bandage, or a clean cloth. 2)If blood soaks through the bandage, place another bandage on top of the first and keep applying pressure. 3)Raise the injured body part to slow bleeding. 4)When bleeding stops, cover the wound with a new, clean bandage.

patterns: How do you treat Diarrhea?
what to do if i get Diarrhea?
Which medicine to take if I get Diarrhea?
How to cure Diarrhea?
responses: 1)Hydrating the body is essential for recovering from diarrhea.This causes the body to lose electrolytes such as sodium and chloride. 2)It is highly recommended to avoid dairy products, as they may worsen diarrhea in some people. 3)However, if diarrhea lasts for more than 2 days, seek medical advice to avoid complications.

patterns: How do you treat a Frost bite?
what to do if i get a Frost bite?
Which medicine to take if I get a Frost bite?
How to cure Frost bite?
responses: 1)Get to a warm room as soon as possible. 2)Unless absolutely necessary, do not walk on frostbitten feet or toes. 3)Immerse the affected area in warm—not hot—water (104°F). 4)Or, warm the affected area using body heat. For example, the heat of an armpit can be used to warm frostbitten fingers. 5)Don't rub the frostbitten area with snow or massage it at all. This can cause more damage. 6)Don't use a heating pad, heat lamp, or the heat of a stove, fireplace, or radiator for warming. Affected areas are numb and can be easily burned. SEEK IMMEDIATE MEDICAL ATTENTION.

patterns: How do you treat Heat Exhaustion?
what to do if i feel Exhausted due to heat?
Which medicine to take if I get Exhausted?
How to cure Heat Exhaustion?
responses: 1)Move to a cool place immediately. Get the person to a shady area or indoors. 2)Remove unnecessary clothing and put on loose, lightweight clothing. 3)Apply cool water to the skin. Use a cool, wet cloth or sponge. 4)Fan the person. Use a fan or newspaper to circulate air. 5)Give cool sports drinks containing salt and sugar if the person is alert and able to drink. 6)Monitor body temperature with a thermometer if available. Continue cooling until body temperature drops to 101-102°F. If symptoms worsen or don't improve within 30 minutes, call 911.

patterns: How do you treat Heat Stroke?
what to do if i get a Heat Stroke?
Which medicine to take if I get Stroke?
How to cure a Heat Stroke?
responses: CALL 911 IMMEDIATELY - Heat stroke is life-threatening. While waiting for help: 1)Move person to cool environment immediately. 2)Remove unnecessary clothing. 3)Try to cool the person's body temperature to 101-102°F using any means available: Put in cool shower or bathtub, spray with garden hose, sponge with cool water, place ice packs or cold wet towels on head, neck, armpits, and groin. 4)Fan the person while applying wet cloths. 5)Monitor breathing and be prepared to give CPR if needed. DO NOT give fluids if person is unconscious or vomiting.

patterns: How do you treat a Insect Bite?
what to do if a insect bites me?
Which medicine to take if I get bitten by a insect?
How to cure insect bite?
responses: 1)Remove the stinger if visible by scraping it out with a credit card or fingernail. Don't squeeze or use tweezers. 2)Wash the area with soap and water. 3)Apply a cold compress for 10-15 minutes to reduce swelling. 4)Apply calamine lotion or a paste of baking soda and water to reduce itching. 5)Take an oral antihistamine like Benadryl for allergic reactions. 6)Watch for signs of severe allergic reaction: difficulty breathing, swelling of face/throat, rapid pulse, dizziness. If these occur, call 911 immediately.

patterns: How do you treat a bleeding nose?
what to do if i my nose is bleeding?
Which medicine to take if I get nose bleed?
How to cure nose bleeding?
responses: 1)Sit upright and lean slightly forward to prevent blood from going down the throat. 2)Pinch the soft part of the nose (just below the bony ridge) with thumb and index finger. 3)Hold firmly for 10-15 minutes without letting go or checking if bleeding stopped. 4)Breathe through the mouth. 5)Apply ice pack to the bridge of the nose. 6)After bleeding stops, avoid blowing nose for several hours. If bleeding doesn't stop after 20 minutes or if caused by injury, seek medical attention.

patterns: How do you treat a Pulled Muscle?
what to do if my muscle is pulled?
Which medicine to take if I got pulled muscle?
How to cure a pulled muscle?
responses: Follow R.I.C.E protocol: 1)REST - Avoid activities that cause pain or muscle spasm. 2)ICE - Apply ice pack for 15-20 minutes every 2-3 hours for first 48 hours. 3)COMPRESSION - Use elastic bandage, but not too tight. 4)ELEVATION - Raise the injured area above heart level when possible. 5)Take over-the-counter pain relievers like ibuprofen or acetaminophen. 6)After 48 hours, gentle heat and light stretching may help. Seek medical attention if severe pain, numbness, or inability to move the muscle.

patterns: How do you treat Rectal Bleeding?
what to do if i get a Rectal Bleeding?
Which medicine to take if I get Rectal Bleeding?
How to cure Rectal Bleeding?
responses: Rectal bleeding requires medical evaluation. Immediate steps: 1)Stay calm and note the amount and color of blood. 2)Clean the area gently with warm water. 3)Apply a clean, dry cloth to absorb blood. 4)Avoid straining during bowel movements. 5)Do not insert anything into the rectum. 6)Seek medical attention promptly. Call 911 if bleeding is heavy, you feel faint, have severe abdominal pain, or show signs of shock (rapid pulse, dizziness, cold skin).

patterns: How do you treat Sun Burn?
what to do if i get a Sun Burn?
Which medicine to take if I get Sun Burn?
How to cure a Sun Burn?
responses: 1)Get out of the sun immediately. 2)Take cool (not cold) baths or showers. Add baking soda or oatmeal to bath water for relief. 3)Apply aloe vera gel or moisturizer while skin is still damp. 4)Drink extra water to prevent dehydration. 5)Take ibuprofen or aspirin to reduce inflammation and pain. 6)Don't break blisters if they form. 7)Apply cool, damp cloths to burned areas. 8)Avoid products with petroleum, benzocaine, or lidocaine. Seek medical care if you have fever, chills, severe blistering, or signs of infection.

patterns: How do you treat Testicle Pain?
what to do if i get a Testicle Pain?
Which medicine to take if I get a Testicle Pain?
How to cure Testicle Pain?
responses: Testicle pain can be serious and requires medical evaluation. Immediate care: 1)Support the testicles with snug underwear or athletic supporter. 2)Apply ice pack wrapped in cloth for 15-20 minutes. 3)Take over-the-counter pain medication. 4)Lie down with a pillow between legs for support. SEEK IMMEDIATE MEDICAL ATTENTION if pain is severe, sudden onset, accompanied by nausea/vomiting, fever, or if testicle appears twisted or swollen. Testicular torsion is a medical emergency.

patterns: How do you treat a Vertigo?
what to do if i get a Vertigo?
Which medicine to take if I get Vertigo?
How to cure a Vertigo?
responses: 1)Sit or lie down immediately when you feel dizzy. 2)Use two or more pillows to prop up your head when lying down. 3)Avoid sudden position changes - move slowly from lying to sitting to standing. 4)Avoid bright lights, TV, or reading during an episode. 5)Stay hydrated and avoid alcohol, caffeine, and tobacco. 6)If driving, pull over immediately and wait for dizziness to pass. 7)Consider ginger tea or over-the-counter motion sickness medication. Seek medical attention if vertigo is severe, persistent, or accompanied by hearing loss, severe headache, fever, or numbness.

patterns: How do you treat bleeding?
what to do if i get a Bleeding?
Which medicine to take if I get bleeding?
How to cure Bleeding?
responses: 1)Apply direct pressure to the wound with a clean cloth, sterile bandage, or even a piece of clothing. 2)If blood soaks through, do not remove the original cloth. Add more layers on top and continue pressure. 3)Elevate the bleeding area above the heart if possible. 4)If bleeding is from an arm or leg and won't stop, apply pressure to pressure points. 5)Do not remove objects embedded in wounds. 6)Call 911 for severe bleeding, if bleeding won't stop after 10 minutes of direct pressure, or if person shows signs of shock.

patterns: How do you treat an eye Injury?
what to do if i get a eye Injury?
Which medicine to take if I injured my eye?
How to cure injured eye?
responses: 1)Do NOT rub, press, or apply pressure to the eye. 2)Do NOT try to remove objects stuck in the eye. 3)For chemical splashes: Flush eye immediately with clean water for at least 15-20 minutes. Remove contact lenses if easily removable. 4)For cuts or punctures: Cover both eyes with sterile gauze to prevent eye movement. 5)For small particles: Try to flush out with clean water or artificial tears. 6)Apply cold compress gently for pain from blunt injuries. SEEK IMMEDIATE MEDICAL ATTENTION for any serious eye injury, vision changes, or persistent pain.

patterns: How do you treat a chemical burn?
what to do if i get a Chemical Burn?
Which medicine to take if I get burn due to chemicals?
How to cure Chemical Burn?
responses: 1)IMMEDIATELY flush the area with large amounts of cool, clean water for at least 20 minutes. 2)Remove contaminated clothing and jewelry while flushing. 3)Continue flushing until emergency services arrive. 4)Do NOT apply ointments, butter, or home remedies. 5)Do NOT try to neutralize the chemical with other substances. 6)Cover the burn loosely with sterile gauze. 7)Remove contact lenses if chemicals splashed in eyes while flushing. CALL 911 IMMEDIATELY for all chemical burns. Time is critical - begin flushing before calling if possible.

patterns: How do you treat a Poison?
what to do if i get Poison?
Which medicine to take if I am poisoned?
How to cure Poisoning?
responses: CALL POISON CONTROL: 1-800-222-1222 (US) IMMEDIATELY. 1)If person is unconscious, not breathing, or having convulsions, call 911 first. 2)Try to identify the poison and have the container available when calling. 3)Follow instructions from poison control exactly. 4)Do NOT induce vomiting unless specifically told to do so. 5)Do NOT give activated charcoal unless instructed. 6)If poison is on skin, remove contaminated clothing and flush with water. 7)If poison is in eyes, flush with clean water for 15-20 minutes. 8)Keep the person calm and monitor breathing.

patterns: How do you treat broken Teeth ?
what to do if my Teeth got broken?
Which medicine to take if I get broken teeth?
cure broken teeth?
responses: 1)Rinse mouth gently with warm water to clean the area. 2)Apply cold compress to outside of mouth to reduce swelling. 3)Save any broken tooth fragments in milk or saliva. 4)If tooth is completely knocked out, gently rinse it (do not scrub) and try to place it back in the socket, or store in milk. 5)Take over-the-counter pain medication for discomfort. 6)Avoid very hot or cold foods and drinks. 7)SEEK DENTAL CARE IMMEDIATELY - time is critical for saving teeth. Call emergency dentist or go to emergency room.

patterns: How do you treat a seizure?
what to do if i get a seizure?
Which medicine to take if I get seizure?
How to cure seizure?
responses: DO NOT put anything in the person's mouth. 1)Stay calm and stay with the person. 2)Clear the area of hard or sharp objects. 3)Place something soft under their head. 4)Turn them on their side to help keep airway clear. 5)Time the seizure - if it lasts more than 5 minutes, call 911. 6)Do NOT hold them down or try to stop their movements. 7)Do NOT give water, food or medications during seizure. 8)After seizure, comfort the person as they may be confused. Call 911 if: first seizure, seizure lasts over 5 minutes, person doesn't wake up, or if injured during seizure.

patterns: How do you treat a head Injury?
what to do if i get a Head Injury?
Which medicine to take if I get injured in the head?
How to cure Head Injury?
responses: CALL 911 for severe head injuries. For minor head injuries: 1)Apply ice pack wrapped in cloth to reduce swelling for 15-20 minutes. 2)Watch for signs of concussion: confusion, dizziness, nausea, headache, memory problems. 3)Keep person awake and alert for first few hours. 4)Monitor for worsening symptoms. 5)Do NOT give aspirin (may increase bleeding risk). 6)Acetaminophen is OK for headache. SEEK IMMEDIATE MEDICAL ATTENTION if: loss of consciousness, severe headache, repeated vomiting, seizures, slurred speech, weakness in limbs, or increasing confusion.

patterns: How do you treat Faint?
what to do if i feel like Fainting?
Which medicine to take if I get a Faint?
How to cure Fainting?
responses: If someone is about to faint: 1)Have them sit down and put their head between their knees, or lie down with legs elevated 8-12 inches. 2)Loosen tight clothing around neck. 3)Ensure good air circulation. If someone has fainted: 1)Check for breathing and pulse. 2)Position on their back with legs elevated. 3)Loosen tight clothing. 4)Apply cool, damp cloth to forehead. 5)Do NOT give food or drink until fully conscious. 6)Most people recover quickly. Call 911 if person doesn't regain consciousness within a minute, has difficulty breathing, or if fainting was preceded by chest pain.

patterns: How do you treat a mild Headache?
what to do if i get a mild Headache?
Which medicine to take if I have a mild headache?
How to cure a mild headache?
responses: Give ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin), aspirin, or acetaminophen (Tylenol) for pain. Avoid ibuprofen and other NSAIDs if the person has heart failure or kidney failure. Do not give aspirin to a child under age 18.

patterns: How do you treat a Cold?
what to do if i get a mild Cold?
Which medicine to take if I have a Cold?
How to cure Cold?
responses: 1)Keeping hydrated is absolutely vital to help 'flush' out the cold, as well as to break down congestion and keep your throat lubricated. 2)Vitamin C is extremely helpful when fighting infection, so at the first sign of a cold be sure to increase your intake by eating plenty of berries, citrus fruits, papayas, broccoli and red peppers which will help keep you protected. 3)When it comes to combating a cold,Vitamin D is essential in helping to regulate immune response.

patterns: How do you treat Rashes?
what to do if i get a Rash?
Which medicine to take if I have a Rash?
How to cure Rash?
responses: 1)Olive oil helps in healing and promotes skin renewal given it is packed with vitamin E and antioxidants. It also soothes the skin and reduces itching. 2)Baking soda is useful in drying skin rashes as also in relieving itching and inflammation. 3)Aloe Vera,Thanks to its antibacterial, antifungal, anti-inflammatory and emollient properties, aloe vera is excellent for treating a number of skin ailments including rashes as also soothing the skin.

patterns: How do you treat a snake bite?
what to do if i get a snake bite?
Which medicine to take if I get a snake bite?
How to cure snake bite?
i got bit by a snake
responses: While waiting for medical help: 1)Move the person beyond striking distance of the snake. 2)Have the person lie down with wound below the heart. 3)Keep the person calm and at rest, remaining as still as possible to keep venom from spreading. 4)Cover the wound with loose, sterile bandage. 5)Remove any jewelry from the area that was bitten. 6)Remove shoes if the leg or foot was bitten.

patterns: How do you treat a animal bite?
How do you treat a monkey bite?
How do you treat a dog bite?
what to do if i get a animal bite?
Which medicine to take if I get a monekey bite?
How to cure dog bite?
i got bit by a dog
responses: 1)Wash the wound with soap and warm water. 2)Gently press a clean cloth over the wound to stop the flow of blood. 3)Apply an antibacterial ointment to the wound. 4)Cover with a sterile bandage. 5)Watch for signs of infection. 6)Seek help if you suspect infection or possible exposure to rabies, or if the wound is severe.

patterns: What to do if someone is Drowning?
what to do if someone drowned?
What steps to take if i see a drowning person?
How to help a drowning person?
responses: 1)Place your ear next to the person's mouth and nose. Do you feel air on your cheek? 2)Look to see if the person's chest is moving.If the Person is Not Breathing, Check Pulse. 3)Check the person's pulse for 10 seconds.If There is No Pulse, Start CPR.

patterns: How to give CPR??
what to do in a CPR?
What steps to take in a CPR??
How to help a drowning person in CPR?
responses: 1)For an adult or child, place the heel of one hand on the center of the chest at the nipple line. You can also push with one hand on top of the other. For an infant, place two fingers on the breastbone. 2)For an adult or child, press down at least 2 inches. Make sure not to press on ribs. For an infant, press down about 1 and 1/2 inches. Make sure not to press on the end of the breastbone. 3)Do chest compressions only, at the rate of 100-120 per minute or more. Let the chest rise completely between pushes. 4)Check to see if the person has started breathing.

patterns: How do you treat a Fracture?
what to do if i get a Fracture?
Which medicine to take if I have a Fracture?
How to cure a Fracture?
responses: 1)Stop any bleeding. Apply pressure to the wound with a sterile bandage, a clean cloth or a clean piece of clothing. 2)Immobilize the injured area. Don't try to realign the bone or push a bone that's sticking out back in. If you've been trained in how to splint and professional help isn't readily available, apply a splint to the area above and below the fracture sites. Padding the splints can help reduce discomfort. 3)Apply ice packs to limit swelling and help relieve pain. Don't apply ice directly to the skin. Wrap the ice in a towel, piece of cloth or some other material. 4)Treat for shock. If the person feels faint or is breathing in short, rapid breaths, lay the person down with the head slightly lower than the trunk and, if possible, elevate the legs.

patterns: How do you treat a stab wound?
what to do if someone is stabbed?
Which medicine to apply for stab wounds?
How to help someone who was stabbed?
stab wound first aid
responses: CALL 911 IMMEDIATELY. 1)DO NOT remove the object if still embedded - this may cause more bleeding. 2)Apply direct pressure around the wound, not on the embedded object. 3)Use sterile gauze or clean cloth to control bleeding. 4)If no embedded object, apply direct pressure to wound. 5)Keep person lying down and still. 6)Monitor breathing and pulse. 7)Cover with sterile bandage. 8)Watch for signs of shock: pale skin, rapid pulse, weakness. 9)Do NOT give food or water. CRITICAL: Deep stab wounds can damage internal organs even if external bleeding seems minor.

patterns: How do you treat a gunshot wound?
what to do if someone is shot?
gunshot wound first aid
How to help someone who was shot?
bullet wound treatment
responses: CALL 911 IMMEDIATELY. 1)Ensure scene is safe before approaching. 2)Apply direct pressure to bleeding wounds with sterile gauze or clean cloth. 3)DO NOT remove any clothing stuck to the wound. 4)If entrance and exit wounds, treat both. 5)Keep person lying down and still. 6)Monitor breathing - be prepared to perform CPR. 7)Do NOT give food or water. 8)Watch for shock: pale skin, rapid weak pulse, confusion. 9)If person is conscious, try to keep them calm and talking. 10)Do NOT try to remove bullets or bullet fragments. TIME IS CRITICAL - get professional medical help immediately.

patterns: How do you treat a heart attack?
what to do if someone has a heart attack?
heart attack first aid
signs of heart attack
chest pain emergency
responses: CALL 911 IMMEDIATELY. 1)Help person sit down and rest in comfortable position (slightly upright). 2)Loosen tight clothing around neck and chest. 3)If person takes heart medication (nitroglycerin), help them take it. 4)Give aspirin if person is not allergic (chew, don't swallow whole). 5)Monitor breathing and pulse - be ready to perform CPR. 6)Stay calm and reassure the person. 7)Do NOT leave person alone except to call for help. Signs: chest pain/pressure, pain in arm/jaw/back, shortness of breath, nausea, sweating, dizziness. Even if symptoms improve, continue to seek immediate medical attention.

patterns: How do you treat a stroke?
what to do if someone has a stroke?
stroke first aid
signs of stroke
brain attack
responses: CALL 911 IMMEDIATELY - Time is critical! Use F.A.S.T. to identify stroke: FACE drooping, ARM weakness, SPEECH difficulty, TIME to call 911. 1)Note time symptoms started. 2)Keep person calm and lying down with head and shoulders slightly elevated. 3)Do NOT give food or water - swallowing may be impaired. 4)Loosen tight clothing. 5)If person is unconscious, place in recovery position. 6)Monitor breathing and be prepared to perform CPR. 7)Do NOT give medications unless prescribed for stroke. Other signs: sudden severe headache, vision problems, dizziness, loss of balance. EVERY MINUTE COUNTS - brain tissue dies quickly without blood flow.

patterns: How do you treat a panic attack?
what to do during panic attack?
anxiety attack help
panic attack first aid
breathing problems anxiety
responses: 1)Stay calm and speak in a reassuring, calm voice. 2)Help the person sit down in a quiet place. 3)Encourage slow, deep breathing: breathe in for 4 counts, hold for 4, exhale for 6. 4)Remind them this will pass - panic attacks typically last 5-20 minutes. 5)Help them focus on physical sensations: name 5 things they can see, 4 they can touch, 3 they can hear. 6)Avoid saying 'calm down' or 'relax' - instead say 'you're safe' and 'this will pass'. 7)Stay with them until symptoms subside. Call 911 if: first panic attack, symptoms don't improve after 20 minutes, or if you suspect heart attack (chest pain, sweating, nausea).

patterns: How do you treat allergic reaction?
what to do for severe allergy?
anaphylaxis first aid
allergic reaction emergency
allergy attack
responses: For SEVERE reaction (anaphylaxis) - CALL 911 IMMEDIATELY: 1)Use epinephrine auto-injector (EpiPen) if available - inject into outer thigh. 2)Have person lie down with legs elevated unless breathing is difficult. 3)Monitor breathing and be ready to perform CPR. For MILD reaction: 1)Remove or avoid the allergen. 2)Apply cool compress to affected skin. 3)Give antihistamine (Benadryl) if available. 4)Watch for worsening symptoms. SEVERE signs requiring 911: difficulty breathing, swelling of face/throat, rapid pulse, dizziness, widespread rash, vomiting. Do NOT give oral medications if person is having trouble swallowing.

patterns: How do you treat burns?
what to do for burn injury?
thermal burn first aid
fire burn treatment
heat burn
responses: 1)Remove person from heat source and remove burning clothing (unless stuck to skin). 2)Cool the burn with cool (not cold) running water for 10-20 minutes. 3)Remove jewelry and tight clothing before swelling starts. 4)Cover burn with sterile gauze bandage - do not use cotton. 5)Do NOT apply ice, butter, oils, or home remedies. 6)Take over-the-counter pain medication if needed. 7)Keep person warm to prevent shock. CALL 911 for: burns larger than 3 inches, burns on face/hands/feet/genitals, third-degree burns (white or charred skin), burns caused by chemicals or electricity, or if person shows signs of shock.

patterns: How do you treat electrocution?
what to do for electrical shock?
electric shock first aid
electrical injury
shocked by electricity
responses: 1)DO NOT touch the person if still in contact with electrical source. 2)Turn off power source at circuit breaker if possible, or use non-conductive object (dry wood, plastic) to separate person from source. 3)CALL 911 IMMEDIATELY. 4)Check for breathing and pulse - be prepared to perform CPR. 5)Look for burns at entry/exit points and treat as thermal burns. 6)Keep person lying down and still. 7)Monitor for shock: pale skin, rapid pulse, weakness. 8)Do NOT move person unless in immediate danger - electrical shock can cause spinal injuries. Even minor electrical shocks can cause internal injuries not visible externally.

patterns: How do you treat hypothermia?
what to do for extreme cold exposure?
hypothermia first aid
body temperature too low
freezing cold injury
responses: CALL 911 - Hypothermia is life-threatening. 1)Move person to warm, dry place gently. 2)Remove wet clothing carefully. 3)Warm person gradually: wrap in blankets, use warm (not hot) water bottles on trunk. 4)Give warm, non-alcoholic, non-caffeinated drinks if person is conscious and able to swallow. 5)Do NOT rub or massage areas - this can cause heart problems. 6)Do NOT use direct heat (heating pad, hot water). 7)Monitor breathing and be ready to perform CPR. 8)Handle person very gently - rough movement can trigger dangerous heart rhythms. Signs: shivering, confusion, slurred speech, drowsiness, loss of coordination.

patterns: How do you treat a concussion?
what to do for head trauma?
concussion first aid
brain injury symptoms
head bump injury
responses: CALL 911 if person lost consciousness, is vomiting repeatedly, or has severe symptoms. 1)Keep person awake and alert for first few hours. 2)Apply ice pack to injured area for 15-20 minutes. 3)Monitor for worsening symptoms every 2-4 hours. 4)Allow person to rest in dark, quiet room. 5)Give acetaminophen for headache (NOT aspirin or ibuprofen). 6)No alcohol or recreational drugs. RED FLAGS - Call 911: repeated vomiting, severe headache that worsens, seizures, slurred speech, weakness in arms/legs, increasing confusion, loss of consciousness. Person should see doctor even for mild concussion symptoms.

patterns: How do you treat shock?
what to do for medical shock?
shock first aid
low blood pressure emergency
circulatory shock
responses: CALL 911 IMMEDIATELY - Shock is life-threatening. 1)Lay person down with legs elevated 8-12 inches (unless spinal injury suspected). 2)Keep person warm with blankets but do not overheat. 3)Loosen tight clothing. 4)Do NOT give food or water. 5)Monitor breathing and pulse - be ready to perform CPR. 6)If vomiting, turn person on side to prevent choking. 7)Stay with person and provide reassurance. Signs of shock: pale/clammy skin, rapid weak pulse, rapid breathing, weakness, nausea, confusion, anxiety. Shock can result from blood loss, severe burns, allergic reactions, or other serious injuries.

patterns: How do you treat overdose?
what to do for drug overdose?
overdose first aid
too much medication
drug poisoning emergency
responses: CALL 911 IMMEDIATELY. 1)Try to determine what substance was taken and how much. 2)If person is unconscious but breathing, place in recovery position. 3)If not breathing, begin CPR. 4)Do NOT induce vomiting unless poison control instructs you to. 5)If opioid overdose suspected and naloxone (Narcan) available, administer according to instructions. 6)Stay with person until help arrives. 7)Collect pill bottles, packages, or samples of substance if safe to do so. 8)Monitor breathing and pulse continuously. Signs: confusion, difficulty breathing, blue lips/fingernails, slow pulse, loss of consciousness, seizures.

patterns: How do you treat chest pain?
what to do for chest pain?
chest pain first aid
heart pain emergency
chest pressure
responses: ASSUME HEART ATTACK - CALL 911 IMMEDIATELY. 1)Have person sit down and rest in comfortable position. 2)Loosen tight clothing around neck and chest. 3)If person takes nitroglycerin, help them take it as prescribed. 4)Give aspirin if person is not allergic and can swallow (chew, don't swallow whole). 5)Monitor breathing and pulse - be ready to perform CPR. 6)Stay calm and reassure person. 7)Do NOT leave person alone except to call for help. 8)Note time symptoms started. Even if pain improves, still need immediate medical attention as heart attacks can have varying symptoms.

patterns: How do you treat breathing problems?
what to do for shortness of breath?
breathing difficulty first aid
can't breathe emergency
respiratory distress
responses: CALL 911 if severe breathing difficulty. 1)Help person sit upright or in position most comfortable for breathing. 2)Loosen tight clothing around neck and chest. 3)If person has rescue inhaler, help them use it. 4)Encourage slow, deep breathing if person is hyperventilating. 5)Stay calm and reassure person. 6)Monitor for signs of severe distress: blue lips/fingernails, inability to speak, extreme anxiety. 7)Be prepared to perform CPR if person stops breathing. 8)Do NOT give food or water. CALL 911 immediately if: person cannot speak due to breathing difficulty, blue coloration, or if this is a new/worsening problem.

patterns: How do you treat unconsciousness?
what to do if someone passes out?
unconscious person first aid
person won't wake up
passed out emergency
responses: CALL 911 IMMEDIATELY. 1)Check for responsiveness - tap shoulders and shout 'Are you OK?'. 2)Check for breathing and pulse. If absent, begin CPR immediately. 3)If breathing normally, place in recovery position (on side). 4)Do NOT give food, water, or medications. 5)Do NOT slap or splash water on face. 6)Keep airway clear - tilt head back slightly, lift chin. 7)Monitor breathing and pulse continuously. 8)Look for medical alert bracelets/necklaces. 9)If person vomits, turn to side to prevent choking. 10)Keep person warm but do not overheat. Stay with person until medical help arrives.
